elements.content: This work presents eight coordination assemblies based on divalent metal ions (M = CoII, CuII, ZnII, and CdII), dicyanamide anion (N(CN)2 −, dca), and two isomeric bent dipyridyl coligands (L), namely, 2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (3-bpo) and 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (4-bpo). In the resulting crystalline materials, both bpo and dca tectons generally display the bidentate bridging fashion (except in the mononuclear species 5), extending the metal centers to afford diverse one-, two-, and three-dimensional (1-D, 2-D, and 3-D) coordination networks that are not commonly observed in M−dca−L systems. Notably, the inclined polycatenated 2-D → 3-D framework and 3-D polyknotting network with the unique 6-connected (44.611) topology are formed for the CuII and CdII species with dca and 4-bpo. For the polymeric CoII and CuII complexes, very weak antiferromagnetic or ferromagnetic interactions are observed between the metal centers due to the μ1,5-bridging mode of dca, and their magneto-structural correlations have been discussed in detail. The ZnII and CdII complexes show solid-state fluorescent emissions at room temperature.

In the resulting crystalline materials, both bpo and dca tectons generally display the bidentate bridging fashion (except in the mononuclear species 5), extending the metal centers to afford diverse one-, two-, and three-dimensional (1-D, 2-D, and 3-D) coordination networks that are not commonly observed in M-dca-L systems. Notably, the inclined polycatenated 2-D → 3-D framework and 3-D polyknotting network with the unique 6-connected (44.611) topology are formed for the CuII and CdII species with dca and 4-bpo. For the polymeric CoII and CuII complexes, very weak antiferromagnetic or ferromagnetic interactions are observed between the metal centers due to the μ1,5-bridging mode of dca, and their magneto-structural correlations have been discussed in detail. The ZnII and CdII complexes show solid-state fluorescent emissions at room temperature.

elements.content: Syntheses, structural analyses, and solid-state properties (magnetism and fluorescence) of metal dicyanamide complexes incorporating two isomeric dipyridyl tectons, 2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole and 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole, are presented, which show diverse coordination motifs (from 0-D to 3-D) and supramolecular crystalline lattices.
elements.clean_text: Syntheses, structural analyses, and solid-state properties (magnetism and fluorescence) of metal dicyanamide complexes incorporating two isomeric dipyridyl tectons, 2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole and 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole, are presented, which show diverse coordination motifs (from 0-D to 3-D) and supramolecular crystalline lattices.

elements.content: In the past decade, the realm of crystal engineering has achieved significant success in developing a variety of coordination networks, and their available properties for potential applications in gas storage, catalysis, ion exchange, as well as optical, electric, and magnetic devices, etc. Synthetic strategies for such well-characterized crystalline solids are of great importance for realizing their predictable coordination assemblies, generally based on the principle of modular construction or building-block methodology. In this connection, the rational design of suitable molecular tectons (linkers) is most critical, which can extend the metal ions in a predetermined fashion to produce target network-based materials with specific structures and properties. In this context, net topology is an essential issue for understanding and further manipulating the complicated coordination networks, and currently, considerable efforts have been focused on entangling networks, such as polycatenation and polyknotting structural prototypes that are also relevant to biological and pharmaceutical systems.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past decade, the realm of crystal engineering has achieved significant success in developing a variety of coordination networks, and their available properties for potential applications in gas storage, catalysis, ion exchange, as well as optical, electric, and magnetic devices, etc. Synthetic strategies for such well-characterized crystalline solids are of great importance for realizing their predictable coordination assemblies, generally based on the principle of modular construction or building-block methodology. In this connection, the rational design of suitable molecular tectons (linkers) is most critical, which can extend the metal ions in a predetermined fashion to produce target network-based materials with specific structures and properties. In this context, net topology is an essential issue for understanding and further manipulating the complicated coordination networks, and currently, considerable efforts have been focused on entangling networks, such as polycatenation and polyknotting structural prototypes that are also relevant to biological and pharmaceutical systems.

elements.content: Recently, we have systematically explored the coordination assemblies on the basis of two bent dipyridyl isomers (see Scheme ), 2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (3-bpo) and 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (4-bpo), which demonstrate that both ligands can act as reliable building blocks to construct multiform metallosupramolecular architectures. On the other hand, the dicyanamide anion (N(CN)2 −, dca), is a versatile tecton for tailoring coordination frameworks with interesting magnetic behaviors. Of further importance, although the binary M(dca)2 species are very limited, large numbers of ternary coordination networks can be readily formed by introducing organic coligands into assembling systems. In this work, by combining both the dca anion and 3-bpo or 4-bpo ligand as the building blocks, we have synthesized a series of new CoII, CuII, ZnII, and CdII complexes, which display diversified structures due to the inherent coordination discrepancy of metal ions and the isomeric effect of organic ligands. Their unusual structural features such as network topology and entanglement have been analyzed in detail. Solid-state properties (magnetism and fluorescence) for the related crystalline materials will also be presented.

With the exception of the ligands 3-bpo and 4-bpo that were prepared according to the literature methods, all reagents and solvents were commercially available. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were carried out on a CE-440 (Leemanlabs) analyzer. Fourier transform (FT) IR spectra (KBr pellets) were collected on an AVATAR-370 (Nicolet) spectrometer. elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

With the exception of the ligands 3-bpo and 4-bpo that were prepared according to the literature methods, all reagents and solvents were commercially available. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were carried out on a CE-440 (Leemanlabs) analyzer. Fourier transform (FT) IR spectra (KBr pellets) were collected on an AVATAR-370 (Nicolet) spectrometer. Solid-state fluorescence spectra were measured on a Cary Eclipse spectrofluorimeter (Varian) at room temperature.

elements.content: Magnetic measurements for 1, 2, and 6 were carried out in the “Servei de Magnetoquímica (Universitat de Barcelona)” on polycrystalline samples (20−30 mg) with a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS-XL susceptometer, working in the 2−300 K temperature range at the magnetic field of 0.1 T. The diamagnetic corrections were evaluated from Pascal’s constants. The EPR spectra of 6, varying the temperature in the 4−300 K range, were recorded on a powder sample at X-band frequency with a Bruker 300E automatic spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Studies

Magnetic measurements for 1, 2, and 6 were carried out in the "Servei de Magnetoquímica (Universitat de Barcelona)" on polycrystalline samples (20-30 mg) with a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS-XL susceptometer, working in the 2-300 K temperature range at the magnetic field of 0.1 T. The diamagnetic corrections were evaluated from Pascal's constants. The EPR spectra of 6, varying the temperature in the 4-300 K range, were recorded on a powder sample at X-band frequency with a Bruker 300E automatic spectrometer.

elements.content: To a mixture of 3-bpo (22.4 mg, 0.1 mmol) and Na(dca) (18.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) in CH3OH/CH3CN (V/V = 1/1, 15 mL) was added an aqueous solution (10 mL) of Co(ClO4)2·6H2O (73.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) with stirring for 30 min. The resulting light red precipitate was filtered off and the filtrate was left to stand at room temperature. Red lamellar single crystals of complex 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained after ca. 3 weeks in 66% yield (27.3 mg, based on 3-bpo). Anal. elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for complexes 1−8 (CCDC reference numbers: 770630−770637) were collected on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. There was no evidence of crystal decay during data collection. In each case, a semiempirical absorption correction was applied (SADABS) and the program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS and refined with SHELXL. The non-hydrogen atoms were modeled with anisotropic displacement parameters and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2. Generally, C-bound H atoms were placed geometrically and refined as riding, whereas O-bound H atoms were first located in difference Fourier maps and then fixed in the calculated sites. In the structure of 3, methanol and nitrate were found to coexist with one of the dca anions, and their occupancy ratios were uniformly refined to 0.5. Further crystallographic details are summarized in Table . Selected bond parameters and important H-bonding geometries are shown in , respectively.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for complexes 1-8 (CCDC reference numbers: 770630-770637) were collected on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. There was no evidence of crystal decay during data collection. In each case, a semiempirical absorption correction was applied (SADABS) and the program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS and refined with SHELXL. The non-hydrogen atoms were modeled with anisotropic displacement parameters and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2. Generally, C-bound H atoms were placed geometrically and refined as riding, whereas O-bound H atoms were first located in difference Fourier maps and then fixed in the calculated sites. In the structure of 3, methanol and nitrate were found to coexist with one of the dca anions, and their occupancy ratios were uniformly refined to 0.5. Further crystallographic details are summarized in Table . Selected bond parameters and important H-bonding geometries are shown in , respectively.

Complexes 1−8 were prepared using direct solution assemblies of different metal ions with 3-/4-bpo and Na(dca) in moderate yields. All complexes are air stable and were characterized by elemental analyses and IR spectra. In the IR spectra of 1−8, the absorption bands appearing in 1400−1600 cm−1 can be ascribed to the skeletal vibrations of the aromatic groups of 3-/4-bpo. For the IR spectrum of Na(dca), three sharp and strong characteristic stretch peaks in 2286, 2232, and 2179 cm−1 can be assigned to νas + νs(C−N), νas(C≡N), and νs(C≡N) of the dca anion, respectively. The corresponding peaks of dca are also observed in the IR spectra of 1−8, and the shift and/or split of such bands may be ascribed to their different metal complexations. Additionally, the IR spectra of 3 and 6 display very strong characteristic adsorption bands in 1360 and 1384 cm−1, respectively, indicating the presence of nitrate anions.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Preparation and IR Spectra of 1-8 

Complexes 1-8 were prepared using direct solution assemblies of different metal ions with 3-/4-bpo and Na(dca) in moderate yields. All complexes are air stable and were characterized by elemental analyses and IR spectra. In the IR spectra of 1-8, the absorption bands appearing in 1400-1600 cm-1 can be ascribed to the skeletal vibrations of the aromatic groups of 3-/4-bpo. For the IR spectrum of Na(dca), three sharp and strong characteristic stretch peaks in 2286, 2232, and 2179 cm-1 can be assigned to νas + νs(C-N), νas(C≡N), and νs(C≡N) of the dca anion, respectively. The corresponding peaks of dca are also observed in the IR spectra of 1-8, and the shift and/or split of such bands may be ascribed to their different metal complexations. Additionally, the IR spectra of 3 and 6 display very strong characteristic adsorption bands in 1360 and 1384 cm-1, respectively, indicating the presence of nitrate anions.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complexes 1 and 3 are isostructural, except that one dca anion in 1 is replaced by disordered dca, nitrate, and methanol in 3. As a result, only the crystal structure of 1 is discussed herein, in which the octahedral CoII center is six-coordinated by two 3-bpo and four dca (see Figure a). The Co−N bond lengths are in the range of 2.091(4)−2.176(4) Å (see ). Interestingly, paired cisoid-3-bpo ligands and μ1,5-dca anions link two adjacent CoII centers to afford a bimetallic cage-like pattern (Co···Co = 7.383(6) Å), and such [Co2(3-bpo)2(dca)2] dimeric subunits are further extended by the single μ1,5-dca bridges (Co···Co = 7.587(3) Å) to form a two-dimensional (2-D) layered network (see Figure b). From the viewpoint of network topology, each CoII ion is a 3-connected node and all ligands are 2-connected spacers, and thus, the resulting layer has a (6,3) topology. Alternatively, if each bimetallic unit is considered as a net node, a more familiar (4,4) topology is formed. Interlayer π···π stacking interactions are observed between the adjacent oxadiazole rings of parallel 3-bpo ligands, with a centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.481(3) Å, which will stabilize the final three-dimensional (3-D) supramolecular lattice (see Figure c).

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complexes 1 and 3 are isostructural, except that one dca anion in 1 is replaced by disordered dca, nitrate, and methanol in 3. As a result, only the crystal structure of 1 is discussed herein, in which the octahedral CoII center is six-coordinated by two 3-bpo and four dca (see Figure a). The Co-N bond lengths are in the range of 2.091(4)-2.176(4) Å (see ). Interestingly, paired cisoid-3-bpo ligands and μ1,5-dca anions link two adjacent CoII centers to afford a bimetallic cage-like pattern (Co⋅⋅⋅Co = 7.383(6) Å), and such [Co2(3-bpo)2(dca)2] dimeric subunits are further extended by the single μ1,5-dca bridges (Co⋅⋅⋅Co = 7.587(3) Å) to form a two-dimensional (2-D) layered network (see Figure b). From the viewpoint of network topology, each CoII ion is a 3-connected node and all ligands are 2-connected spacers, and thus, the resulting layer has a (6,3) topology. Alternatively, if each bimetallic unit is considered as a net node, a more familiar (4,4) topology is formed. Interlayer π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions are observed between the adjacent oxadiazole rings of parallel 3-bpo ligands, with a centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.481(3) Å, which will stabilize the final three-dimensional (3-D) supramolecular lattice (see Figure c).

elements.content: Complex 2 has a one-dimensional (1-D) double chain structure, and the asymmetric unit consists of one CuII ion, one 3-bpo, two dca anions, and one lattice CH3CN. The CuII center adopts an octahedral geometry (see Figure a), linking to two 3-bpo and two dca at the equatorial plane (Cu−N = 1.953(5)−2.053(5) Å) as well as another two dca locating at the apical positions (Cu−N = 2.453(5) and 2.622(6) Å), indicating a significant Jahn−Teller elongation. The paired dca anions connect the CuII ions to form a 1-D array along [100], with the nearest Cu···Cu separation of 7.322(2) Å that is equal to the length of a axis. Two such adjacent 1-D arrays are further combined by the cisoid-3-bpo ligands in pairs (Cu···Cu = 7.875(9) Å) to form a 1-D double chain (see Figure b). Analysis of the crystal packing reveals that the 3-bpo ligands thereof are also available for π···π stacking contacts, occurring between the pyridyl (N4) and oxadiazole rings with a centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.525(7)/3.811(6) Å and a dihedral angle of 5.8°. As a result, the 1-D double chains in an interdigitated arrangement are further extended via π···π stacking interactions to form a 2-D supramolecular net (see Figure c). In addition, the lattice CH3CN solvents are located at the interspace between such parallel 2-D networks, with no significant secondary interaction being observed.

elements.content: Complex 4 has a 1-D ladder-like coordination motif based on the dimeric [Cd2(3-bpo)2(dca)2] secondary building units (SBUs). Both CdII ions in the fundamental unit adopt a slightly distorted octahedral geometry (average Cd−N length = 2.326 Å for Cd1 and 2.335 Å for Cd2), which are linked by paired 3-bpo ligands and μ1,5-dca anions with a Cd···Cd separation of 7.823(1) Å (see Figure a). Furthermore, another pair of symmetry-related μ1,5-dca anions around each CdII sphere leads to the connection of such adjacent dimeric units, affording a 1-D ladder-like polymeric array (Cd···Cd = 7.4189(6) Å) along the [100] direction (see Figure b). Additionally, such parallel 1-D arrays are also arranged in an interdigitated mode, and again, π···π stacking interactions are observed between the neighboring 3-bpo segments, giving a 2-D supramolecular array (see Figure c). However, the π···π interactions in this case occur between the oxadiazole and pyridyl rings (centroid-to-centroid distance = 3.948(2) Å, dihedral angle = 4.0°) as well as between the pyridyl rings (centroid-to-centroid distances = 3.718(2)−3.940(2) Å, dihedral angles = 0−3.3°). And also, such 2-D motifs adopt a parallel arrangement, between which the lattice CH3CN molecules are accommodated without any significant secondary interaction.

elements.content: Complex 5 is a neutral mononuclear molecule with centrosymmetry (see Figure a), in which the CoII ion is six-coordinated by four nitrogen donors from two 4-bpo ligands and two dca anions adopting the unidentate mode, as well as two water molecules. Notably, two coordinated and two lattice water molecules are connected via O2−H2B···O3 and O3−H3B···O2 interactions (see for details) to form a cyclic water tetramer with uudd configuration. As a result, the mononuclear motifs are extended by such water−water interactions to produce a 1-D array along the [100] axis (Figure b). On the other hand, each water ligand is hydrogen bonded to the oxadiazole ring (O2−H2A···N3), leading to the formation of a 2-D layered architecture (see Figure c). In addition, H-bonds between the lattice water moieties and uncoordinated pyridyl rings (O3−H3A···N1) are also observed, and thus, result in a 3-D H-bonding architecture (see Figure d).

elements.content: Complex 6 shows an entangling network featuring a 2-D → 3-D inclined polycatenation. Two types of CuII ions with elongated octahedral coordination spheres exist (see Figure a), which both consist of four nitrogen donors of two 4-bpo and two dca ligands in the equatorial plane (Cu−N = 1.938(2)−2.058(2) Å), as well as two water molecules at the axial sites (Cu−O = 2.341(2) and 2.620(2) Å). Both dca and 4-bpo behave as the bidentate bridges, which extend the CuII ions to afford a 2-D (4,4) network (see Figure b), with the Cu···Cu separation of 8.090(5) and 13.763(3) Å, respectively. Notably, these layers are distributed along two different orientations ([12̅2̅] and [122̅]) to afford two sets of arrays in parallel−parallel arrangements. Consequently, a 2-D → 3-D inclined polycatenated supramolecular pattern is constructed (see Figure c), with the angle between two inclined layers of 86.9°. Similar examples for polycatenating coordination frameworks based on (4,4) layers have been reported previously. Additionally, the lattice water molecules and nitrate anions are located in the resulting 3-D host framework, with the presence of multiform H-bonding interactions (see for details).

elements.content: There are two distinct ZnII centers in the structure of 7, in which Zn1 lies on an inversion center and has a distorted octahedral geometry, provided by paired 4-bpo, μ1,5-dca, and aqua ligands, whereas the distorted tetrahedral coordination sphere of Zn2 is furnished by one 4-bpo, one μ1,5-dca, one unidentate dca, and one chloride (see Figure a). As a result, the 4-bpo and μ1,5-dca connectors in tandem bridge the ZnII ions to form a 1-D box-like array (Zn···Zn = 13.743(7) and 7.852(6) Å) along the [11̅1] axis (see Figure b), within which π···π stacking interactions are observed between the adjacent oxadiazole groups of 4-bpo with a centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.574(3) Å. In addition, each water ligand is H-bonded to the unidentate dca anion (O2−H2A···N10), interlinking the 1-D arrays to afford a 2-D layered network (see Figure c). Interlayer O2−H2B···Cl interactions further extend such 2-D motifs to result in a 3-D supramolecular architecture (see Figure d).

elements.content: Complex 8 is a unique 3-D 6-connected self-penetrating network, in which two crystallographically independent CdII ions with similar octahedral coordination spheres (consisting of two 4-bpo plus four μ1,5-dca) are observed (see Figure a). With the aid of 4-bpo and one type of dca (containing N8−N9−N10), a 2-fold parallel interpenetrating pattern of the grid-like layers is afforded (see Figure b), arising from that the layer is highly undulated as a consequence of the bent backbones of both 4-bpo and dca connectors (Cd···Cd = 14.121(3) and 8.421(2) Å). These 2-fold interpenetrating arrays stack in a parallel mode along [101] and are interconnected by additional dca bridges (containing N5−N6−N7) to produce a single 3-D coordination network (see Figure c). This structure seems rather complicated, and thus, a topology simplification should be helpful to further understand its structural nature. In this connection, each CdII center can be regarded as 6-connnected node, and all ligands are 2-connected spacers. Thus, the resulting 3-D network can be ascribed to a uninodal (44.611) topology. Significantly, several types of 6-connected networks such as acs, crs, icy, kag, and the most familiar pcu, have been reported thus far, and however, such a unique network observed in 8 is obviously different to the known examples. Another unusual feature for this case is polyknotting (or self-penetrating), since the resulting single network is generated from the linkage of 2-fold interpenetrating 2-D patterns, in which each shortest four-membered ring is intercrossed by two other ones of the same 3-D network (see Figure d).

elements.content: The structural features of 1−8 are summarized in Table . In all structures, the metal centers normally adopt the octahedral coordination except the Zn2 ion in 7 with a tetrahedral geometry. As for the bpo ligands and dca anion, both types of building components mostly act as the bidentate bridging tectons in the resulting coordination patterns, and their structural diversity should be mainly attributed to the metal ions with different coordination tendencies and/or the positional isomeric effect of 3-/4-bpo. Generally, the 3-bpo ligand takes the cisoid-conformation and behaves as the bidentate connector. As a result, the reliable bimetallic motif [M2(3-bpo)2] is uniformly observed in 1−4, and the extension of such dimeric SBUs via μ1,5-bridging dca anions in different manners leads to the formation of three types of coordination networks. As for 4-bpo, a mononuclear CoII complex 5 is obtained with unidentate 4-bpo and dca terminals, and diverse coordination architectures are constructed for 6−8 via both 4-bpo and dca spacers, indicating a metal-directed assembly. Notably, similar 2-D [M(4-bpo)(dca)] n layers are observed in the structures of 6 and 8, which however, are arranged in the inclined polycatenating (6) and 2-fold parallel interpenetrating (8) fashions, respectively. As a result, a 2-D → 3-D entangled net is formed in 6, and the interpenetrated motifs in 8 are further interconnected by dca to afford a unique 3-D self-penetrating architecture. In addition, secondary interactions are also critical to construct the overall supramolecular lattices of 1−7, in which significant π···π stacking and/or H-bonding contacts are observed.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Comparison for 1-8 

The structural features of 1-8 are summarized in Table . In all structures, the metal centers normally adopt the octahedral coordination except the Zn2 ion in 7 with a tetrahedral geometry. As for the bpo ligands and dca anion, both types of building components mostly act as the bidentate bridging tectons in the resulting coordination patterns, and their structural diversity should be mainly attributed to the metal ions with different coordination tendencies and/or the positional isomeric effect of 3-/4-bpo. Generally, the 3-bpo ligand takes the cisoid-conformation and behaves as the bidentate connector. As a result, the reliable bimetallic motif [M2(3-bpo)2] is uniformly observed in 1-4, and the extension of such dimeric SBUs via μ1,5-bridging dca anions in different manners leads to the formation of three types of coordination networks. As for 4-bpo, a mononuclear CoII complex 5 is obtained with unidentate 4-bpo and dca terminals, and diverse coordination architectures are constructed for 6-8 via both 4-bpo and dca spacers, indicating a metal-directed assembly. Notably, similar 2-D [M(4-bpo)(dca)] n  layers are observed in the structures of 6 and 8, which however, are arranged in the inclined polycatenating (6) and 2-fold parallel interpenetrating (8) fashions, respectively. As a result, a 2-D → 3-D entangled net is formed in 6, and the interpenetrated motifs in 8 are further interconnected by dca to afford a unique 3-D self-penetrating architecture. In addition, secondary interactions are also critical to construct the overall supramolecular lattices of 1-7, in which significant π⋅⋅⋅π stacking and/or H-bonding contacts are observed.

The χM T vs T plot for 1 (χM is the molar magnetic susceptibility for one CoII ion) is shown in Figure a. The χM T value at 300 K is 3.5 cm3 mol−1 K, which continuously decreases to 2.1 cm3 mol−1 K at 12 K. At a lower-temperature region (from 12 to 2 K), there are significant differences for the χM T values applying small magnetic fields, indicating the presence of a small amount of ferromagnetic or canted antiferromagnetic-ordered impurities, likely, α- or β-[Co(dca)2] with T c at 9−10 K. To confirm this opinion, ac susceptibility measurements were performed (see ), which reveal a T c value of 9 K. Notably, this feature (presence of magnetic ordered impurities) is very common for CoII−dca−L systems. The reduced magnetization curve (Figure a, inset) at 2 K tends to 2.5 Νβ/Co at 5 T, which is a typical value for a quasi-isolated Co2+ ion. At this stage, it is impossible to fit the magnetic data of 2-D CoII systems such as complex 1, owing to the existence of λ (spin−orbit coupling), A (measure of the strength of the crystal field), and J. Theoretically, it may be possible to calculate an estimated J value using the two-exponential Rueff expression, which is suitable for any temperature greater than the possible T c. In this case, the small J value expected by the μ1,5-bridging dca ligands, which always result in almost negligible coupling parameters, and the presence of impurities of [Co(dca)2] avoid achieving any physically meaningful fitting.

Magnetic Properties

The χM T vs T plot for 1 (χM is the molar magnetic susceptibility for one CoII ion) is shown in Figure a. The χM T value at 300 K is 3.5 cm3 mol-1 K, which continuously decreases to 2.1 cm3 mol-1 K at 12 K. At a lower-temperature region (from 12 to 2 K), there are significant differences for the χM T values applying small magnetic fields, indicating the presence of a small amount of ferromagnetic or canted antiferromagnetic-ordered impurities, likely, α- or β-[Co(dca)2] with T c at 9-10 K. To confirm this opinion, ac susceptibility measurements were performed (see ), which reveal a T c value of 9 K. Notably, this feature (presence of magnetic ordered impurities) is very common for CoII-dca-L systems. The reduced magnetization curve (Figure a, inset) at 2 K tends to 2.5 Νβ/Co at 5 T, which is a typical value for a quasi-isolated Co2+ ion. At this stage, it is impossible to fit the magnetic data of 2-D CoII systems such as complex 1, owing to the existence of λ (spin-orbit coupling), A (measure of the strength of the crystal field), and J. Theoretically, it may be possible to calculate an estimated J value using the two-exponential Rueff expression, which is suitable for any temperature greater than the possible T c. In this case, the small J value expected by the μ1,5-bridging dca ligands, which always result in almost negligible coupling parameters, and the presence of impurities of [Co(dca)2] avoid achieving any physically meaningful fitting.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of 2 as the χM T vs T plot (χM is the molar magnetic susceptibility for two CuII ions) and the reduced magnetization (M/Nβ vs H) are depicted in Figure b. The χM T value at 300 K is 0.88 cm3 mol−1 K, being as expected for two magnetically quasi-isolated spin doublets (g > 2.00). Starting from room temperature, the χM T values are practically constant to 50 K, below which they decrease quickly to 0.70 cm3 mol−1 K at 2 K, revealing a characteristic of very weak antiferromagnetic interactions. The reduced molar magnetization (see Figure b, inset) at 2 K clearly corroborates that the antiferromagnetic coupling is very small, with the M/Nβ value at 5 T being close to 0.9 Nβ/Cu. Complex 2 is actually a 1-D CuII entity with dca bridges and dinuclear subunits. The pathway via dca is equatorial (short)−apical (long), which usually results in a very weak magnetic coupling, and in the dinuclear subunit via long 3-bpo connectors, the coordination is equatorial (short)−equatorial (short). The fit of the susceptibility data has been carried out using two possible methods: (a) assuming that the main magnetic pathway is that forming the dinuclear subunit through 3-bpo, the best-fit parameters obtained using the Bleaney−Bowers formula, are J = −1.21 ± 0.1 cm−1, g = 2.18 ± 0.01, and R = 2.1 × 10−5 (see Figure b); (b) considering as a 1-D entity in which each CuII center is linked to the neighbors through dca, the best-fit parameters obtained using the model for a uniform antiferromagnetic S = 1/2 chain are J = −0.66 ± 0.1 cm−1, g = 2.18 ± 0.01, and R = 1.1 × 10−6 (see ). In both cases, although the J values are different, the magnitude is very small and negative, indicating a weak antiferromagnetic coupling. This feature can be interpreted as a consequence of the almost nil overlap in both magnetic pathways that likely are operative at the same time.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of 6 are shown in Figure c as the χM T vs T plot (χM is the molar magnetic susceptibility for one CuII ion). The χM T value at 300 K is 0.455 cm3 mol−1 K, which is as expected for one magnetically quasi-isolated spin doublet (g > 2.00). Starting from room temperature, the χM T values stand practically constant to 50 K and then smoothly increase to 0.516 cm3 mol−1 K at 2 K. The χM T measurements were made under 500 and 10000 G, without any noticeable modification. The reduced magnetization (M/Nβ) at 2 K (see Figure c inset) follows practically the Curie law for the g value of 2.15 (according to the ESR spectrum, see ). X-band powder EPR spectra at different temperatures are unchanged with the g values of g // = 2.25 and g ⊥ = 2.10. The global features are characteristic of very weak ferromagnetic interactions. Complex 6 is actually a 2-D system, in which the CuII centers are separated by dca and 4-bpo spacers, and the coupling must be very small in both cases. Considering its structural features and mainly the small difference between the χM T values at 2 K and room temperature, no fit is possible by using the formula given by Kahn for such ferromagnetic CuII systems, which is only valid at the high temperature region.

elements.content: As for the 1-D systems with μ1,5-dca bridges, the small J values do not allow one to draw accurate magneto-structural correlations, and the only possible thing is to compare these values for similar complexes. In this regard, Julve et al. have summarized the most important features for this kind of complexes. There are some conclusions that can be underlined as follows: (a) the J value is normally very small or nil, except in one antiferromagnetic case; (b) when there are two dca bridges between the adjacent CuII ions that show distorted octahedral environments (Jahn−Teller effect), almost all complexes do not have magnetic coupling (J ≈ 0 cm−1) within the experimental error; (c) when there is only one dca bridge between the adjacent CuII ions that are pentacoordinated, a major variety of J values (from −3.3 cm−1 to +0.2 cm−1) are observed. When the CuII ions take the equatorial−equatorial coordination mode, the weak coupling via the extended dca bridges can be understood as follows: the magnetic orbital describing the unpaired electron on a CuII center in square-pyramidal or elongated distorted octahedral geometry is of the d x 2 −y 2 type (the x and y axes being roughly defined by the short equatorial bonds). The overlap between two such orbitals via the polyatomic μ1,5-dca bridge is expected to be very weak. As a consequence, the antiferromagnetic coupling, which is proportional to the square of this overlap, is predicted to be a weak one as observed.

In this regard, Julve et al. have summarized the most important features for this kind of complexes. There are some conclusions that can be underlined as follows: (a) the J value is normally very small or nil, except in one antiferromagnetic case; (b) when there are two dca bridges between the adjacent CuII ions that show distorted octahedral environments (Jahn-Teller effect), almost all complexes do not have magnetic coupling (J ~ 0 cm-1) within the experimental error; (c) when there is only one dca bridge between the adjacent CuII ions that are pentacoordinated, a major variety of J values (from -3.3 cm-1 to +0.2 cm-1) are observed. When the CuII ions take the equatorial-equatorial coordination mode, the weak coupling via the extended dca bridges can be understood as follows: the magnetic orbital describing the unpaired electron on a CuII center in square-pyramidal or elongated distorted octahedral geometry is of the d  x 2   -y 2  type (the x and y axes being roughly defined by the short equatorial bonds). The overlap between two such orbitals via the polyatomic μ1,5-dca bridge is expected to be very weak. As a consequence, the antiferromagnetic coupling, which is proportional to the square of this overlap, is predicted to be a weak one as observed.

elements.content: As for the explanation of the ferromagnetic coupling observed in complex 6, a similar case for Ni(II) species has been reported, and the theoretical calculation for this type of coordination systems with μ1,5-dca bridges has also been performed. According to these results, for M−N−C(dca) bond angles around 160°, there is the possibility of accidental orthogonality for d8 and d9 ions, and these angles in 6 are 167.9(2) and 174.2(2)°. On the other hand, the existence of 4-bpo bridging ligands and the network packing can also contribute to the magnetic coupling. Notably, the positive J parameter in 6 represents the first experimental evidence of the model predicted above for a CuII complex with μ1,5-dca bridges.

elements.content: Solid-state emission spectra of the ZnII (3 and 7) and CdII (4 and 8) complexes as well as the 3-/4-bpo ligands were studied to explore their potential for hybrid luminescent materials. As depicted in Figure , excitation of the microcrystalline samples affords different fluorescent emissions, with the maximum peaks occurring at 393 nm for 3-bpo, 361 nm for 3, and 365 nm for 4 (λex = 345 nm) as well as 417 nm for 4-bpo, 353 nm for 7, and 522 nm for 8 (λex = 370 nm). For 3 and 4, the very similar profiles of their emission peaks, in comparison with that of the free 3-bpo ligand, demonstrate that their photoluminescent mechanism can be properly attributed to intraligand transitions. In addition, the blue-shift for these bands should arise from the effect of metal−ligand coordination interactions. The related results of complex 7 are comparable. With regard to complex 8, the significant red shift of the emission band (105 nm) compared with that of 4-bpo may arise from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT).
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Properties

Solid-state emission spectra of the ZnII (3 and 7) and CdII (4 and 8) complexes as well as the 3-/4-bpo ligands were studied to explore their potential for hybrid luminescent materials. As depicted in Figure , excitation of the microcrystalline samples affords different fluorescent emissions, with the maximum peaks occurring at 393 nm for 3-bpo, 361 nm for 3, and 365 nm for 4 (λex = 345 nm) as well as 417 nm for 4-bpo, 353 nm for 7, and 522 nm for 8 (λex = 370 nm). For 3 and 4, the very similar profiles of their emission peaks, in comparison with that of the free 3-bpo ligand, demonstrate that their photoluminescent mechanism can be properly attributed to intraligand transitions. In addition, the blue-shift for these bands should arise from the effect of metal-ligand coordination interactions. The related results of complex 7 are comparable. With regard to complex 8, the significant red shift of the emission band (105 nm) compared with that of 4-bpo may arise from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT).

elements.content: This work suggests that the combination of bent dipyridyl ligands and dca anion as building blocks is an effective approach to construct unusual network-based coordination materials, in virtue of different metal ions and ligand isomerism. These experimental results will enrich the current building-block methodology and provide new insights into its application in engineering such crystalline solids with desired structures and properties. Further efforts on the design and preparation of novel coordination networks with other bent dipyridyl tectons and pseudohalide anions are underway in our lab.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions and Perspective

This work suggests that the combination of bent dipyridyl ligands and dca anion as building blocks is an effective approach to construct unusual network-based coordination materials, in virtue of different metal ions and ligand isomerism. These experimental results will enrich the current building-block methodology and provide new insights into its application in engineering such crystalline solids with desired structures and properties. Further efforts on the design and preparation of novel coordination networks with other bent dipyridyl tectons and pseudohalide anions are underway in our lab.

cln_elements.content:

cln_elements.content: The magnetic properties of 2 as the χM T vs T plot (χM is the molar magnetic susceptibility for two CuII ions) and the reduced magnetization (M/Nβ vs H) are depicted in Figure b. The χM T value at 300 K is 0.88 cm3 mol−1 K, being as expected for two magnetically quasi-isolated spin doublets (g > 2.00). Starting from room temperature, the χM T values are practically constant to 50 K, below which they decrease quickly to 0.70 cm3 mol−1 K at 2 K, revealing a characteristic of very weak antiferromagnetic interactions. The reduced molar magnetization (see Figure b, inset) at 2 K clearly corroborates that the antiferromagnetic coupling is very small, with the M/Nβ value at 5 T being close to 0.9 Nβ/Cu. Complex 2 is actually a 1-D CuII entity with dca bridges and dinuclear subunits. The pathway via dca is equatorial (short)−apical (long), which usually results in a very weak magnetic coupling, and in the dinuclear subunit via long 3-bpo connectors, the coordination is equatorial (short)−equatorial (short). The fit of the susceptibility data has been carried out using two possible methods: (a) assuming that the main magnetic pathway is that forming the dinuclear subunit through 3-bpo, the best-fit parameters obtained using the Bleaney−Bowers formula, are J = −1.21 ± 0.1 cm−1, g = 2.18 ± 0.01, and R = 2.1 × 10−5 (see Figure b); (b) considering as a 1-D entity in which each CuII center is linked to the neighbors through dca, the best-fit parameters obtained using the model for a uniform antiferromagnetic S = 1/2 chain are J = −0.66 ± 0.1 cm−1, g = 2.18 ± 0.01, and R = 1.1 × 10−6 (see ). In both cases, although the J values are different, the magnitude is very small and negative, indicating a weak antiferromagnetic coupling. This feature can be interpreted as a consequence of the almost nil overlap in both magnetic pathways that likely are operative at the same time.
